intro.text: Willing Hands is a body posture that signals openness and acceptance. Through this practice, you'll learn how physical openness can create mental and emotional acceptance, even in challenging situations.

sections.title: Willing Hands Posture
steps: Sit or stand comfortably with your arms at your sides
Turn your palms to face upward, fingers relaxed and slightly curved
Let your shoulders drop and soften
Relax your facial muscles, especially around your jaw and forehead
Breathe naturally and notice the feeling of openness
sections.quote: This posture signals to your nervous system that you're open to whatever comes, reducing the body's natural tendency to brace against difficulty.

sections.title: Body Scan with Willing Hands
sections.instructions: Adopt the willing hands posture and spend 5 minutes scanning your body from head to toe. Notice where you hold tension when you feel resistance or stress.
guideSteps: Start at the top of your head, notice any tension
Move to your forehead, eyes, jaw, and neck
Feel your shoulders, arms, and hands
Notice your chest, back, and stomach
Scan your hips, legs, and feet
When you find tension, breathe into that area and soften
sections.question: Where did you notice tension in your body?
sections.placeholder: Describe the areas where you felt tension or resistance...

sections.title: Set Your Intention
sections.instructions: Think of a situation that feels stressful or challenging. Adopt the willing hands posture and set an intention for acceptance and calm in that situation.
sections.question1: What situation will you practice willing hands with?
sections.placeholder1: Describe the areas where you felt tension or resistance...
subSectionSteps: Visualize yourself in the challenging situation
Set an intention to remain open and calm
Notice how the posture affects your mindset

sections.placeholder2: Write your intention for approaching this situation with willing hands...

sections.title: Reflection & Integration
sections.instructions: Reflect on your willing hands practice. How did it feel to adopt this posture of openness? What did you learn about your relationship with resistance and acceptance?
sections.question: How did the willing hands practice feel? What did you learn?
